rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:30
rsbNotes.text: 21:30 The appearance of leaves on the trees announces that summer is at hand. So the signs tell us that the kingdom is near.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:32
rsbNotes.text: 21:32 generation. The Greek word usually means all the people alive at a given time, but it can also mean all of a certain kind of people (e.g., wicked or righteous). The term can also mean “race”; if this is the meaning here it signifies that the Jews will continue to the end.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:36
rsbNotes.text:
21:36 stay awake . . . praying. Watchfulness and prayer are Christian duties to the end of time.

to stand before the Son of Man. This signifies salvation at the last day.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:37–38
rsbNotes.text: 21:37, 38 Jesus’ last days were spent teaching in Jerusalem, while at night He stayed on the Mount of Olives nearby.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 22:1
rsbNotes.text: 22:1 the Feast . . . Passover. Strictly speaking, Passover and the Feast of Unleavened Bread were different but immediately successive festivals (Num. 28:26, 27), but by New Testament times the names were used interchangeably. The feast commemorated the great deliverance of Israel from Egypt (Ex. 12:17; Mark 14:1 note).

rsbNotes.title: Luke 22:2
rsbNotes.text: 22:2 chief priests. The chief priests had the political power among the Jews and they, not the Pharisees, led the final opposition to Jesus.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 22:3–6
rsbNotes.text: 22:3–6 Satan took control of Judas (John 13:2), and it was Judas who sought the chief priests, not they who sought him. The “officers” of the temple guard were mostly Levites.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 22:7
rsbNotes.text: 22:7 Passover. According to Ex. 12:5 the animal could be a lamb or a young goat. It would be killed at twilight (Ex. 12:6).

rsbNotes.title: Luke 22:8–12
rsbNotes.text: 22:8–12 Jesus was ready to die, but at the time of His own choosing. This may be the reason for the way Jesus made arrangements for the feast. None of the disciples knew where they would eat it.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 22:10
rsbNotes.text: 22:10 carrying a jar. A man carrying a pitcher of water would stand out, because pitchers were used by women, and men carried water in skins.
